snippet: A state appeals court ruled on Friday that the police could close marijuana buyers' clubs despite a state law that made it legal to use marijuana for medicinal purposes.    Such clubs would set a precedent for ''marijuana to be sold as a loss lead...
lead_paragraph: A state appeals court ruled on Friday that the police could close marijuana buyers' clubs despite a state law that made it legal to use marijuana for medicinal purposes. Such clubs would set a precedent for ''marijuana to be sold as a loss leader or at cost in co-ops, grocery stores, liquor stores etc., or to be provided on a complimentary basis at bars, restaurants, nightclubs or casinos,'' said the ruling from the First District Court of Appeals. It held that Proposition 215, which was approved by voters in 1996 and which permitted the medical use of marijuana, did not legalize such groups.
abstract: State appeals court in California rules that police could close marijuana buyers' clubs despite state law that makes it legal to use marijuana for medicinal purposes; says law did not legalize such clubs (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Marijuana Clubs Illegal, California Court Rules
